sections.title: Preface
sections.summary: The preface explains the purpose of this handbook as a practical guide to implementing the ideas from The Forgotten Ways. Written with Darryn Altclass, it addresses the common reader question of how to apply Apostolic Genius principles in real-world contexts. It provides an overview of the book's structure, including summaries of mDNA elements, suggested habits and practices, and group learning processes designed to help action groups operationalize the forgotten ways of apostolic movements.

sections.title: Introduction to the Forgotten Ways
sections.summary: This introduction provides an overview of Apostolic Genius, the latent power within God's people that energized remarkable movements like the early church and the Chinese underground church. It explores how these movements grew exponentially despite having none of the typical church resources, and introduces the six elements of mDNA: Jesus Is Lord, Disciple-Making, Missional-Incarnational Impulse, Apostolic Environment, Organic Systems, and Communitas. The chapter frames the book's central question of how to recover and activate these forgotten ways in contemporary Western contexts.

sections.title: The Heart of It All
sections.summary: This chapter establishes 'Jesus Is Lord' as the foundational element of Apostolic Genius, tracing it from the Shema Yisrael through to the early Christian confession. It explores how remarkable movements distilled their message to its essence and lived by simple Christology, rejecting dualistic separations between sacred and secular. The chapter provides practical habits and practices for keeping Jesus at the heart of all things, including getting over dualism, making the Gospels the primary text, and shaping life, spirituality, missional engagement, and leadership on Jesus.

sections.title: Disciple Making
sections.summary: This chapter emphasizes disciple-making as perhaps the most critical element of mDNA, focusing on becoming like Jesus and embodying his mission. It contrasts authentic disciple-making with the challenge of consumerism and explores how Jesus formed disciples through life-on-life relationships. The chapter provides habits and practices for raising the bar on discipleship, developing disciple-making practices, and activating the priesthood of all believers through empowerment, action-reflection processes, and coaching.

sections.title: Missional-Incarnational Impulse
sections.summary: This chapter explores the twin impulses of missional (outward movement) and incarnational (embedding deep into culture) practices that together seed and embed the gospel. It examines how remarkable movements combined these approaches, with missional referring to the sending nature of God's mission and incarnational referring to identifying with and embedding within host communities. The chapter provides extensive practical guidance on going out (proximity, frequency, spontaneity) and going deep (meaningful engagement, proclamation, holy living, hospitality, contextualizing community, and sending).

sections.title: Apostolic Environment
sections.summary: This chapter explores the apostolic environment needed for Apostolic Genius to flourish, focusing on apostolic leadership's role in embedding, guarding, and creating environments for mDNA. It examines the three primary functions of apostolic ministry: pioneering new ground, guarding mDNA through apostolic theology, and creating environments where other ministries (APEST) emerge. The chapter provides habits and practices for pioneering and multiplying, cultivating Apostolic Genius, fostering community calling and uniqueness, developing ministry capacity, and catalyzing connections and resources.

sections.title: Organic Systems
sections.summary: This chapter explores organic systems as the inner structures that enable exponential, movement-type growth, contrasting them with institutional approaches. It examines how the church should function as a living system with networked structures, viruslike growth, and simplicity for reproducibility. The chapter provides habits and practices for stirring up movement, structuring organically (distributing power, becoming learning organizations, structuring around life and existing energy), networking and communicating extensively, and 'sneezing the gospel' through simplexity, releasing early and often, and aiming for viruslike growth.

sections.title: Communitas, Not Community
sections.summary: This chapter explores communitas as the deep comradeship that emerges from shared ordeal, liminality, and mission, drawing on Victor Turner's anthropological work. It distinguishes communitas from typical community, showing how remarkable movements developed through dangerous journeys and adaptive challenges rather than safe, artificial environments. The chapter provides habits and practices for developing transformative vision, positioning the church within the hub of life, engaging in shared endeavors, and putting adventure back into the venture through risk-taking and experimentation.

sections.title: Resources
sections.summary: This resources section provides practical examples and tools referenced throughout the book, including examples of discipleship norms from various communities (Mosaic, InnerCHANGE), community mission practices (Third Place Communities, Small Boat Big Sea, Red), APEST charting examples, mDNA assessment tools, Lectio Divina practices, Edward de Bono's Six Thinking Hats framework, movie recommendations for communitas themes, and online resources including mPULSE and APEST tests for measuring and developing Apostolic Genius.

sections.title: Glossary of Key Terms
sections.summary: This glossary provides comprehensive definitions of key terms used throughout The Forgotten Ways and this handbook, including Apostolic Genius, mDNA, APEST, missional-incarnational impulse, communitas, liminality, organic systems, and various theological and missiological concepts. It serves as a reference guide for readers navigating the specialized vocabulary of missional ecclesiology, movement dynamics, and apostolic leadership frameworks.

sections.title: Bibliography
sections.summary: This bibliography provides a comprehensive list of sources referenced in The Forgotten Ways, including works on missional church, apostolic ministry, church planting movements, organic systems, communitas, leadership, and related theological and missiological topics. It serves as a resource for further study and deeper engagement with the ideas presented in the handbook.
